prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about a couple where the husband works from home and set up his office in their bedroom despite the wife suggesting the basement. The wife feels that his choice limits her ability to do daily tasks and manage the kids, while the husband is upset when she can't be quiet during his calls.

First, I need to consider the key points. The husband chose the bedroom for a better view, even though the basement was an option for fewer disturbances. The wife has to manage the kids, work, and chores, but the husband's setup is making it hard for her to do even basic things. The question is whether the wife is wrong for not keeping him undisturbed while he works from home.

The user wants to know if the author (the wife) is in the wrong. The options are A (yes) or B (no). 

Looking at the situation, the husband's decision to work in the bedroom creates a conflict because it affects the wife's ability to function. The wife is trying to balance her work and household responsibilities, and the husband's choice complicates that. By choosing the bedroom over the basement, he's prioritizing his comfort over the wife's needs. The wife is not at fault for not being able to stay silent if the root issue is his choice of workspace. The problem seems to stem from the husband's decision, so the wife isn't in the wrong for pushing back. Therefore, the answer should be B (no).
